The Miserable Devastating Dwarf (cleric15/fighter6/weapon master19) by avado
Infernal Thug (Rogue 13/Fighter 12/Cleric 15) by CrispyCritter

I suggest looking for Clc/Ftr/WM or Clc/CoT/WM combos first since WM builds are typically either sculpted for DevCrit or high damage (i.e. STR-focused).  Even if a build doesn't specifically design DevCrit into it, most STR builds can be modified to accomplish that task.  Just be wary that some of the legacy builds were created before v1.69 so may reflect "foreign" concepts using today's perspective (I noticed one of those Ftr 2 club exploit builds in the list I generated).

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Yeah, it really comes down to how many crits will be issued each round and of those, how high a DC will you need to beat the Fort of a non-crit immune.  High Fort types are typically weak-willed so before attacking, cast Bestow Curse to drop their Fort by 1.  That's another 5% better chance to beat the save.

RDD is a pretty automatic exploit to reach the highest DC.  I never consider it myself because the class has been either nerfed or banned everywhere I play and since I like to test out potential toons for LAN/PW gaming in SP modules, there is really no point contriving any.  But for SP only, RDD would be the way to go.  I'd still try to DW kukris, though.  7 APR increases your crit chances by around 30% not even counting the expanded range.  Plus, the higher APR will work out better vs. crit immunes having all those attacks land with divine damage that pierces any DR.

Ponder away, Mick!

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
theflyingrodent wrote:
Assuming no class restrictions or nerfs, it's pretty hard to beat RDD offensively for any strength melee build. COT comes close, but in the case of Cleric, ab can hit the +20 cap before Wrath has a chance to effect it.

Defensively there's a few options though: PM and DD to name a couple.

It is possible to shoehorn in dev and Epic DR III into a cleric rdd, they have the stats for it.

Tanky Duergar dragon Cleric? :)

 
Sure it can.  But there are always trade-offs.  Like most power builds, you'll gain the greatest advantage by focusing on a chosen strength and suffering the consequences of your weaknesses.  A dedicated DevCrit build seeks to crit as often as possible with the highest DC possible.  What's the point in setting up a build to kill on a crit if it loses most of the save rolls?

Investing in CON bumps instead of STR will lower the DevCrit DC.  Also, the skill set will suffer because those initial points invested in CON must come from somewhere, that means low DEX/low INT. 

CoT has little to do with building towards a once-per-day minor damage advantage (the attack bonus counts towards the AB cap which will already be reached with standard divine buffs and GMW with the DR all but worthless in anything but an exalted CHA high level CoT) and everything to do with boosting saves in an otherwise pedestrian saves rating.  For PvM with average AI, a toon can get by with poor saves.  Vs. advanced AI and PvP, it's a recipe for disaster because you are likely to battle what amounts to a "clone" with superior saves and lose the rolls consistently.

A dwarven RDD?  You'll run out of pre-epic feats, suffer casting potential (ala loss of metamagic power) and get hit by a 20% XP penalty the moment you take a bard level (not to mention lose an entire skill).  Human is pretty much essential in a feat-starved combo like this.  It's still just a spellsword with a DevCrit bias.

PM or DwD?  Not sure how either has any relevance in an RDD build.  Subbing either of those for RDD will nerf the DevCrit potential drastically.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Impressive, Mick.   Never woulda thunk you'd have room for a sacrificial WF but right there it is in powder-blue 'n black.

Indispellable by all attempts other than Mords, a buffed DevCrit DC of 43 (46 STR-capped), a dependable critting blade (15-20 just like a kukri), buffed 5 APR, buffed AB of 62 (65 STR-capped), attack versatility (KD/Cleave), all the essential metamagic and a buffed Fort save of 39 (42 CON-capped)... looks like a keeper to me.  For PvP, the two +fort feats should make this fellow near un-DevCrittable (where but AD&D would one find such a word?). Fort 48 + d20... woohoo!

Cleric STR melee helps making the decision about domains a bit easier than a DEXer who needs either War or Animal to fully buff AB/AC/reflex.  Dropping either Trickery or Travel is a tough decision.

I used to always decline Travel if I suspected permahaste was available.  But sometimes it is limiting in the toughest encounters when it comes to buffing hired help and/or a summons.  Inevitably an encounter will occur that requires any deflection the cleric can provide, so hasting your companion and skel chief/grtr mummy can make a huge difference. Besides, I like to see the startled look when my cleric casts a sticky, buggy Web in the enemy's midst. hehehe  I'm beginning to slot Travel domain without further deliberation unless I feel I can solo 1 thru 40, which almost never happens on the servers I play nowadays ("solo" meaning just the PC in the party avatar list at all times).  

But those familiar with WoG will attest to the limitations imposed by a deity package consistent with 3rd edition PnP that limits which domains can be selected.   Every cleric must declare a deity to level as a cleric on WoG.  Of over 30 deities, only Sehanine Moonbow allows Trickery+Travel combo.  Unfortunately, alignment/race restrictions (must be CG/CN elf/halfelf) limits using this build on that server to another deity that is less discriminating and with different domains.  Many challenging mid-magic PWs have implemented either a deity package or some sort of guild system to encourage class balance and diverse build designs.

@ Stagmeister:
Mick Dagger wrote:
"I wanted to add to the challenge and build for undispellable. But I feel that any build with some serious cleric can be worth having a closer look at."
 
When fully buffed, I don't think saves will be a problem.  After CoT10, bonus feats come by slower so more levels are less of a bargain.

It's not that the cleric class is nerfed when following 3.0 rules. Without the system in place, a cleric become a fictitious exploit class... basically a free-lance priest without any accountability to an organized worship system.  Ummm... hello?  We are supposed to be playing an AD&D game here, right?

But then again, Bioware is famous (or perhaps "infamous" is a more accurate description) for releasing many exploitable and buggy features that were never resolved. And that is not limited exclusively to NWN1 either.  But the community knows better, has several expert scripting gurus and designers, and in many cases has restored the AD&D quality to the gaming experience as best they can.  NWN is the closest egame to AD&D around but still has many warts.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: When using CoT for a save boost, keep in mind that the saves boosts from equipment, Spellcraft, and CoT all count towards the +20 cap on saves. In a high-magic environment (like Sands of Fate (and maybe Aielund)) where you an hit the +20 cap with gear and Spellcraft, the saves boost from CoT is wasted. The saves boosts from enhanced abilities and from Paladin or BG do not count towards that +20 cap.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Well, Spellcraft only counts vs. spells DCs.  Against feat DCs like DevCrit, Quivering Palm, Terrifying Rage, etc. only the base saves, ability modifier and universal buffs apply.  So with the CoT10's +5 saves and another +3 from divine buffs, your toon still needs to equip another +12 universal save gear to reach the cap.  If you do that, you are probably sacrificing other properties and ability boosts that are as important or more so. Clerics will equip jewelry to expand spell slots, cap WIS and their primary attack ability, at minimum.  Some damage resistance and/or immunity to fear/mind-effects are also on the short list.  Don't think I've ever sacrificed a gear slot to boost saves.  There are just too many more important priorities to address first (at least as a cleric).

But I agree in regards to high-magic environments. All spellcasters suffer when gear properties and creature skins reduce the advantages of their spells and classes suffer when their special bonuses are neutralized in the same fashion.

Thanks for the warning about Sands of Fate, Empyre.  Hadn't realized it was so gear-oriented.

Hey Mick, the build does look very solid. My only consideration about it would be if indispellability is worth all the extra levels (I'm not sold on either alternative, TBH, so I'll just throw it out there for reflection). I know you like to be indispellable, but I find it more important for melee-based arcane builds than for Clerics (hurts a lot more to lose a Premonition or Spell Mantle than anything a Cleric can cast). What buffs are so vital that you wouldn't want to be dispelled? DP and DF are short-duration, and the rest can be substituted by gear as you level up in most servers (including Aielund). At least the way I play Clerics, indispellability is more of a nice to have thing than a must. What if you went with 15+ Cleric levels and then focused more on either Monk, CoT or both? Something like Monk 6 / Cleric 16 / CoT 18 would grant you "free IKD", more skill points, more skill dumps and higher saves. Basically at the cost 10 CLs. The two feats you lose (Cleric 23 and 26) you get back from CoT 14 and 18, which can also be used to take GW.

What do you think? Would you test this alternative?

Take it EZ!
